block.p: THURSDAY -- Margaret Thatcher was the guest of honor at a benefit dinner for United Cerebral Palsy of New York City at the New York Hilton and received the group's Humanitarian Award.

WEDNESDAY -- The Advertising Council celebrated its 50th anniversary at the Waldorf-Astoria and presented its 38th Public Service Award to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times. The council creates public-service messages, one of its first, in World War II, being "Loose Lips Sink Ships."

WEDNESDAY -- The Animal Medical Center honored Marella Agnelli, Oscar de la Renta and Philip W. Farley, a longtime trustee, with its Humanitarian Awards at the Pierre.
WEDNESDAY -- The Dance Theater of Harlem gave a dinner-dance benefit at the Manhattan Center on West 34th Street, saluting Gayfryd and Saul Steinberg for helping young people.

MONDAY -- Guests at the Historic Hudson Valley fund-raising dinner dance at the Equitable Center each received a basket of apples from the region. The historic-preservaton organization was founded in 1951 by John D. Rockefeller Jr.

More than 1,400 guests applauded Marvin Traub, Bloomingdale's retiring chairman, at a dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria. Leonard Lauder and Ralph Lauren, co-chairmen of the evening, led the tribute, which included songs by members of the Harvard Glee Club. The evening raised $500,000 for the Marvin and Lee Traub Flexible Financial Aid Fund at Harvard to help exceptional students from middle-income families continue their education.
